title: Cultural Systems

metadata.Scope: Languages, education, and festivals across major cultures

epigraph: The elves count in centuries. The humans count in harvests. Veraheim counts everyone.
rawContent: # Cultural Systems > *"The elves count in centuries. The humans count in harvests. Veraheim counts everyone."* | | | |---|---| | **Type** | Reference Document | | **Scope** | Languages, education, and festivals across major cultures | | **Related** | [Thelassian](/factions/thelassian), [Aloria](/factions/aloria), [Veraheim](/factions/veraheim-the-sanctuary) | --- ## Languages ### The Common Tongue A trade language that emerged from centuries of commerce through Veraheim. Functions like English in our world—widespread but not universal. **Who speaks it:** - Merchants, travelers, diplomats: fluent - Border populations: fluent - Urban populations: conversational - Isolated communities: little to none ### Elvish (Thelassian) The native language of the Thelassian. Ancient, complex, and deliberately difficult to master. **Common as a second language:** - Elves who travel or work borders: fluent - Most other elves: conversational with heavy accent - Scholars and diplomats: fluent - Average elf: can communicate but it's clearly a second language *Elves consider Common a "practical necessity" rather than a language worth mastering.* ### Human Tongues (Aloria) The eleven domains have regional dialects, but a shared Alorian language unites the kingdom. **Common proficiency:** - Traders and travelers: fluent - Urban populations: functional - Rural peasants: limited to none - Lords and nobles: fluent (required for diplomacy) ### Drow A dialect of Elvish that diverged centuries ago. Includes: - Silent hand signs for covert communication - Rarely written (evidence is dangerous) - Speaking it openly marks you as drow --- ## Education ### Thelassian (Elves) *See [Thelassian](/factions/thelassian) for the full elven learning system.* Elves learn across decades, not years. Apprenticeships last longer than human lifetimes. Mastery is expected, not exceptional. ### Aloria (Humans) **No formal education system.** Learning happens through: **Apprenticeships:** - Children work young, learn by doing - Skills passed from master to apprentice - Getting your child placed with a good master requires connections - Literacy is rare outside nobility and clergy **For the privileged:** - Noble children have tutors - A few masters take exceptional students - Magic training exists but is separate (see Magic in Aloria) **The reality:** Most Alorians can't read. They learn their trade, their prayers, and their place. ### Veraheim **Minimum education is mandatory.** Every citizen's child attends school. **Core requirements (roughly equivalent to age 12 skills):** - Reading and writing - Basic mathematics - Veraheim history and governance - City rules and regulations - Festival traditions and customs **For late arrivals:** - Adults who join as citizens receive placement assessment - Those below minimum get special tutoring - A dedicated facility exists for adult education - No shame in it—many refugees never had the chance to learn **The philosophy:** Veraheim functions because everyone can read a contract, count their coin, and understand the laws. Ignorance breeds exploitation. --- ## Festivals and Celebrations ### Thelassian Festivals **Elves do not celebrate yearly.** Their festivals follow longer cycles—decades, not seasons. **Key differences from human celebrations:** - A "festival" may last a week or a month - Tied to celestial events, historical anniversaries, or life milestones - Not predictable to outsiders - Deep ritual significance **Common types:** - Remembrance periods (honoring the dead, may last weeks) - Mastery celebrations (when an elf completes a century of study) - Celestial alignments (rare astronomical events) - The Long Silence (mourning period after great loss—can last years) *Humans find elven festivals confusing. "Is it still going? Did it end? Are they sad or celebrating?"* ### Alorian Festivals **Humans celebrate in familiar cycles.** Yearly, seasonal, predictable. **Seasonal festivals:** - **First Thaw** (spring): End of winter, planting begins - **High Sun** (summer): Longest day, midsummer celebrations - **Harvest Home** (autumn): The main celebration—feasting, gratitude - **Long Night** (winter): Shortest day, candles against the dark **Royal observances:** - **Coronation Day**: Anniversary of the current King's crowning - **Founding Day**: Celebrates the Kingdom's establishment **Religious holidays:** - One or two major holy days depending on region and patron deity - Varies by domain—Thornwood celebrates different gods than Eisenwald ### Veraheim Festivals **Veraheim has its own traditions**, blending influences: - **Founding Day**: Celebrates Vera and Thaelen's establishment of the sanctuary - **Tunnel Opening**: Commemorates when trade began flowing - **The Welcoming**: A monthly celebration of new citizens (small, community-focused) - Residents also observe their own cultural festivals privately --- ## See Also - [Thelassian](/factions/thelassian) - Elven culture and education - [Aloria](/factions/aloria) - Human culture - [Veraheim](/factions/veraheim-the-sanctuary) - The neutral sanctuary - [Drow Culture and Society](/peoples/drow-culture-and-society) - Drow language and traditions --- *"An elf's festival lasts longer than a human's education. This tells you everything about how they see time."*
